[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Type confusion] Can an attacker exploit the error downcasting logic by providing errors that have sources but are actually malicious AptosTapError variants, causing them to be processed incorrectly and bypass security checks? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Status code manipulation] At line 22, can an attacker craft a framework error with a malicious status code (e.g., 200 OK or 301 redirect) that gets preserved through set_status(), allowing them to disguise errors as successful responses and potentially bypass client-side error handling? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Security bypass] Does the status code preservation at line 22 validate that the error.status() is within acceptable error ranges (4xx, 5xx), or can framework errors with success codes (2xx) or redirect codes (3xx) be used to create inconsistent API behaviors? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [HTTP smuggling] Can setting arbitrary status codes from framework errors at line 22 be exploited for HTTP response splitting or smuggling attacks if the status code contains special characters or invalid values? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Information disclosure] At line 21, does error.to_string() expose sensitive internal details from framework errors (stack traces, file paths, database connection strings, private keys) that should be sanitized before being sent to clients? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: build_error_response()] [Information disclosure] Does the build_error_response() function at line 29 properly sanitize the error_string parameter, or can framework errors containing sensitive system information leak through to API responses? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Data leakage] Can framework errors triggered by invalid authentication tokens or authorization failures expose information about valid account addresses, private key formats, or internal account structures through the error.to_string() at line 21? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Enumeration attack] Can an attacker use different malformed requests to trigger various framework errors and enumerate valid API endpoints, account addresses, or faucet configuration details through error messages at line 21? Can race conditions in error.has_source() or response construction lead to mixed error responses being sent to wrong clients? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/endpoints/error_converter.rs] [Function: convert_error()] [Async cancellation] If the async convert_error() function is cancelled mid-execution (e.g., client disconnects), can partial error responses be sent or can error state be left corrupted affecting subsequent requests?
